pageContext.claim: “So now the Obama appointed judge on the Census case (Are you a Citizen of the United States?) won’t let the Justice Department use the lawyers that it wants to use. Could this be a first?”
pageContext.analysis: It was not a first. A federal court rule applicable in New York, where U.S. District Judge Jesse Furman is based, requires litigants to show "satisfactory reasons" for subbing out their lawyers in an ongoing case. The Trump administration provided no reasons for attempting to swap out lawyers, let alone satisfactory ones, Furman found. And the lawyer swap would have disrupted the case, which is another factor he had to consider under the court rules.
